title: Consumers are carrying the economy, but what if they balk?
text:
Bloomberg News/Landov Consumer spending is keeping the economy moving.

The consumer literally carried the U.S. economy in the second quarter of 2019. While business and residential investment, net exports and inventories all declined, real personal consumption expenditures rose at a 4.7% annual rate, the largest increase in 4 1/2 years, contributing 3.1 percentage points to the 2% real gross domestic product growth.

Consumer sentiment surveys suggest that all is not well. What if the consumer starts to rein in his spending, which accounts for almost 70% of GDP?

Mark Hulbert explains: Here’s why sour consumer sentiment could sweeten stocks

Global commerce is slowing in response to the trade war with China and an overall increase in tariffs. Residential investment has declined in eight of the last nine quarters and in 10 of the last 13, even with rock-bottom mortgage rates.

Businesses are deferring capital investment until there is more certainty on the trade front. Manufacturing is already in recession, with factory output declining in the last two quarters.

Alternative sources of growth

Without consumer spending to steady the ship of state, it’s hard to see alternate sources of economic growth.

The University of Michigan’s consumer sentiment index posted its largest decline in almost seven years in August, diving 8.6 points to 89.8, the lowest level since October 2016. Both sub-indexes — one an assessment of current conditions, the other of expectations — declined last month.

“The recent decline is due to negative references to tariffs, which were spontaneously mentioned by one-in-three consumers,” according to Richard Curtin, director and chief economist at the University of Michigan Survey of Consumers.

Now read this: Bad news for parents: Trump’s trade war with China will hit back-to-school supplies

And that was before the latest tariffs, mostly on consumer goods, went into effect on Sept. 1. The 15% tariff on roughly $112 billion of Chinese goods targets everything from apparel to footwear to toys to electronic products. President Donald Trump announced plans to increase existing tariffs on $250 billion of Chinese goods from 25% to 30% on Oct. 1. And there’s more to come on Dec. 15, at which point almost all Chinese imports will be subject to tariffs.

Peter Morici explains: How to win the trade war with China

Two surveys, two narratives

The other closely watched survey of consumer confidence, conducted each month by the Conference Board, tells a different story.

That index rebounded 10.4 points in August to 135.7, the highest reading of the year. The present situation index, which reflects respondents’ appraisal of current business and labor market conditions, jumped to its highest level in almost 19 years. The expectations index posted a modest decline.

Which survey is telling the true story?

The widening spread between what consumers think about today and what they think about tomorrow is a warning sign.

As it turns out, the message — in this case, a warning sign — is contained in the divergence between the two surveys, according to economists at Deutsche Bank Securities.

“The present wide gap between the current conditions component of these surveys” — with the Conference Board measure running well ahead of its University of Michigan counterpart — “has reliably preceded recession in the past,” the economists write in a recent research report.

What’s more, the widening gap between the Conference Board’s expectations and present situation indexes is flashing a similar warning. The extreme negative reading right now, which suggests that “consumers are more optimistic about today than about the future,” has presaged a recession in the past, according to Deutsche Bank Securities chief economist Torsten Slok.

Feeling good

To be sure, consumers have every reason to feel good about their present situation. The unemployment rate is hovering near a half-century low. Wages are rising. The biggest problem isn’t finding a job but finding qualified workers to hire, according to businesses.

Are consumers that good at sniffing out turns in the business cycle that we should pay attention to these cautionary signs from confidence indexes?

It sure seems that way. Consumer confidence — specifically the University of Michigan’s consumer sentiment index — was added to the index of leading economic indicators in 1989.

When the LEI was revamped in 2012, the consumer sentiment component was replaced by “consumer expectations about business conditions,” a hybrid measure that was shown to perform better at turning points, according to Ataman Ozyildirim, senior director of economic research at the Conference Board. (The hybrid measure is an average of responses from the Michigan and Conference Board surveys.)

To the extent that expectations about tomorrow drive spending today, it’s not hard to understand why expectations, be they about one’s own financial condition or that of business, provide an early warning sign of turns in the economy.

If tariffs and trade are behind the slide in the University of Michigan survey, as Curtin suggests, then sentiment is apt to deteriorate further.

Contrary to frequent flights of “trade optimism” underpinning the stock market, the trade war isn’t about to resolve itself anytime soon. On Sept. 1, China retaliated with tariffs on $75 billion of U.S. imports.

ISM warning

The Institute for Supply Management’s manufacturing purchasing managers’ index fell to 49.1% in August, the first sub-50 reading — implying a contraction in manufacturing activity — in three years. All of the sub-indexes except supplier deliveries were below the 50 threshold.

The new export orders Index fell 4.8 points to 43.3, the lowest in over 10 years. And only a handful of industries reported growth last month in each of the various categories. For example, three of the 18 manufacturing industries reported an increase in new orders. (The ISM new orders index is also a component of the LEI.)

The proliferation of downbeat economic news, both domestically and globally, is imposing a big burden on the consumer to keep the expansion going.

To the extent that a widening, negative gap between the Conference Board’s consumer expectations and present situation indexes has preceded previous downturns and confirms the message emanating from another prominent leading indicator of recession, an inverted yield curve, policy makers need to be on high-alert for any signs that the consumer is throwing in the towel.
description: Consumer spending is keeping the economy moving, but what happens if consumers pull back?.
